review.title: Topic Modeling of Behavioral Modes Using Sensor Data
review.abstract: The field of Movement Ecology, like so many other fields, is experiencing a period of rapid growth in availability of data. As the volume rises, traditional methods are giving way to machine learning and data science, which are playing an increasingly large part it turning this data into science-driving insights. One rich and interesting source is the bio-logger. These small electronic wearable devices are attached to animals free to roam in their natural habitats, and report back readings from multiple sensors, including GPS and accelerometer bursts. A common use of accelerometer data is for supervised learning of behavioral modes. However, we need unsupervised analysis tools as well, in order to overcome the inherent difficulties of obtaining a labeled dataset, which in some cases is either infeasible or does not successfully encompass the full repertoire of behavioral modes of interest. Here we present a matrix factorization based topic-model method for accelerometer bursts, derived using a linear mixture property of patch features. Our method is validated via comparison to a labeled dataset, and is further compared to standard clustering algorithms.
histories: Invited Extended version of a paper \cite{resheffmatrix} presented at the international conference \textit{Data Science and Advanced Analytics}, Paris, France, 19-21 OCtober 2015
review.COMMENTS: Invited Extended version of a paper \cite{resheffmatrix} presented at the international conference \textit{Data Science and Advanced Analytics}, Paris, France, 19-21 OCtober 2015

sections.heading: 2 Previous Work
sections.text: In fact, most people who are able to move, to move, to move, to move, to move, to move, to move, to move, to move, to move, to move, to move, to move, to move, to move, to move, to move, to move, to move, to move, to move, to move, to move, to move, to move, to move, to move, to move, to move, to move, to move and to move.

sections.heading: 3.1.1 definition: patch in an ACC signal
sections.text: Let s = [s1,..., sN] be an ACC signal of length N. The length range l from index i of s is the sub-vector: [si,..., si + l − 1] so there are N − l + 1 unique ranges in s.

sections.heading: 3.1.2 Codebook Generation
sections.text: As in the case of BoVW, ACC signals and patches do not consist of individual elements. In order to count patches and determine histogram types, we first have to construct a patch code book. We propose the following construction: At a code book size k and a patch length l, all patches with L length are extracted and bundled for each ACC signal in the dataset. Next, we bundle the patches with K means to form k clusters. The resulting k centroids are called a code book. The intuition behind using patches to describe an ACC signal is that behaviors should be definable by the distribution of short-term movements that they consist of. As different behaviors occur in different characteristic timescales, we would like to repeat the process for more than one patch length in order to efficiently capture all relevant ACC patterns.

sections.heading: 3.1.3 Feature Transformation

sections.heading: 4 Results
sections.text: In this section we will be able to compare our methods, and the results will be discussed in the next section.

sections.heading: 5 Discussion
sections.text: As expected, both 0 − 1 and log-loss error plots are decreasing monotonously in the number of clusters (we use the term cluster here for cluster / partition / topic depending on the method to be considered).The most striking result is that while the matrix factorization theme model method is indeed good compared to the other methods in terms of the log-loss metric (Figure 3), it is not quite as good in terms of the 0-1 loss (Figure 4).To better understand this phenomenon, let's take a closer look at the data. Consider an observation in which the animal takes a single step during the 4-second acceleration measurement window, and stands still for the rest of it. To not dramatically underestimate the amount of walking, an observer will consider this sample as walking (In fact, most samples are likely mixtures).

sections.heading: 6 Conclusions
sections.text: In this paper, we describe a matrix factorization-based modeling approach to behavior mode analysis using acceleration data and demonstrate its qualities using a large dataset on motion ecology. While clustering and topic modeling with matrix factorization are by no means a new idea, the novelty here lies in integrating it with patch features (MS-BoP) that theoretically motivate the method to conduct mode analysis in the context of time series sensors. The main contribution of this paper is to present a framework that will enable widespread application of behavior mode analysis in motion ecology and related areas where the determination of motion patterns from remote sensor measurements is needed. We also present the MS-BoP features that can be applicable to many continuous sensor measurements, and show that a linear blending model is warranted when such features are used.

sections.heading: Acknowledgment
sections.text: This work was partially supported by a scholarship from the Israel Science Foundation (ISF) to Prof. Daphna Weinshall.

referenceMentions.context: Invited Extended version of a paper [21] presented at the international conference Data Science and Advanced Analytics, Paris, France, 19-21 OCtober 2015
Wearable devices with various sensors are becoming increasingly popular, with ongoing research into applications to health monitoring [18] and context detection [12].
Wearable devices with various sensors are becoming increasingly popular, with ongoing research into applications to health monitoring [18] and context detection [12].

Many fields of animal behavior and conservation have also began to utilize similar devices in order to remotely monitor the whereabouts and behavior of their research subjects [20], and this has especially been the case in the field of Movement Ecology.
The aim of Movement ecology is to unify research of movement of organisms and aid in the development of a general theory of whole-organism movement [16].

Recent technological advances in tracking tools and especially the appearance of cheap and small GPS devices [9], have driven the field into a period of rapid growth in knowledge and insight [11], and have led to the emergence of various methods of analyzing movement patterns [24].

Recent technological advances in tracking tools and especially the appearance of cheap and small GPS devices [9], have driven the field into a period of rapid growth in knowledge and insight [11], and have led to the emergence of various methods of analyzing movement patterns [24].

Recent technological advances in tracking tools and especially the appearance of cheap and small GPS devices [9], have driven the field into a period of rapid growth in knowledge and insight [11], and have led to the emergence of various methods of analyzing movement patterns [24].

Thus, promoting movement ecology research and the desirable unification across species and movement phenomena requires the development of additional data sources: sensors and tools providing simultaneous information about the movement, energy expenditure and behavior of the focal organisms, together with the environmental conditions they encounter en route [17].

These sensors allow the determination of the acceleration of the tagged animal’s body, and are used as a means of identifying moment-to-moment behavioral modes [30], and estimating energy expenditure [29].

These sensors allow the determination of the acceleration of the tagged animal’s body, and are used as a means of identifying moment-to-moment behavioral modes [30], and estimating energy expenditure [29].
ACC loggers typically record in 1-3 dimensions, either continuously or in short bouts in a constant window [20].

Their output is used to infer behavior, most commonly through supervised machine learning techniques, and energy expenditure using the Overall Dynamic Body Acceleration (ODBA) or related metrics [8,29].

Their output is used to infer behavior, most commonly through supervised machine learning techniques, and energy expenditure using the Overall Dynamic Body Acceleration (ODBA) or related metrics [8,29].
When combined with GPS recordings, acceleration sensors add fine scale information on the variation in animal behavior, and energy expenditure in space and time (see [2] for a recent review).

ACC-based analysis has been used to compute many measures of interest in the field of Movement Ecology, including behavior-specific body posture, movement and activity budgets, measures of foraging effort, attempted food capture events, mortality detection, classifying behavioral modes and more [2].

These measures have facilitated movement-related research for a wide range of topics in ecology and animal behavior [24,2,26,25] as well as other fields of research such as animal conservation and welfare [26,3] and biomechanics [10, 23].

These measures have facilitated movement-related research for a wide range of topics in ecology and animal behavior [24,2,26,25] as well as other fields of research such as animal conservation and welfare [26,3] and biomechanics [10, 23].

First we suggest a patch-codebook descriptor (MS-BoP) of ACC signals reminiscent of ”bag of visual words” descriptors in Computer Vision (see [4,31]).
First we suggest a patch-codebook descriptor (MS-BoP) of ACC signals reminiscent of ”bag of visual words” descriptors in Computer Vision (see [4,31]).

Previous work on behavioral mode analysis using ACC data focused predominantly on supervised learning, with an emphasis on constructing useful features and finding the right classifiers for a specific use, such as monitoring dairy cows [6], or determining the flight type of soaring birds [28].

Previous work on behavioral mode analysis using ACC data focused predominantly on supervised learning, with an emphasis on constructing useful features and finding the right classifiers for a specific use, such as monitoring dairy cows [6], or determining the flight type of soaring birds [28].
In [22], K-means was applied to a representation of the ACC data, to achieve behavior-mode clusters.
In [7,15] a Gaussian Mixture Model (GMM) variant was used to cluster a low-dimensional representation of ACC signals into a small number of useful behavioral modes.
In [7,15] a Gaussian Mixture Model (GMM) variant was used to cluster a low-dimensional representation of ACC signals into a small number of useful behavioral modes.
Non-Negative Matrix Factorization (NNMF) has been studied extensively in the context of clustering [27,13] and topic modeling [1].

Connections have been shown to various popular clustering algorithms such as K-means and spectral clustering [5].
This is by now a standard problem, which can be solved, for instance, using alternating non-negative least squares [27].

A ground truth partitioning of the data was obtained using standard machine learning techniques (see [20,17] for more details regarding the methodology), based on 3815 field observations each of which was assigned one of 5 distinct behavioral modes (Walking, Standing, Sitting, Flapping, Gliding).

Matrix factorization was preformed using the scikit-learn [19] python software library (see [14] for method details).

metadata.abstractText: The field of Movement Ecology, like so many other fields, is experiencing a period of rapid growth in availability of data. As the volume rises, traditional methods are giving way to machine learning and data science, which are playing an increasingly large part it turning this data into science-driving insights. One rich and interesting source is the bio-logger. These small electronic wearable devices are attached to animals free to roam in their natural habitats, and report back readings from multiple sensors, including GPS and accelerometer bursts. A common use of accelerometer data is for supervised learning of behavioral modes. However, we need unsupervised analysis tools as well, in order to overcome the inherent difficulties of obtaining a labeled dataset, which in some cases is either infeasible or does not successfully encompass the full repertoire of behavioral modes of interest. Here we present a matrix factorization based topic-model method for accelerometer bursts, derived using a linear mixture property of patch features. Our method is validated via comparison to a labeled dataset, and is further compared to standard clustering algorithms.
